1. Your full name: Mrs. Lena Kernan Bacon

2. Your address: 81 Canada, Girvin, Sask.

3. Date June - 1944

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Reutegen, Switzerland

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Fredric C. Kernan, a farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) June 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. New County Nebraska

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? You do not need to answer this question, if you would rather not or you may say "I was a small child."

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To take a homestead and care for my child and myself financially.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

My father visited Western Canada, fell in love with the prospect of wheat farming. He brought a section of land one mile north of Girvin, Sask., and came home with an order for homestead land - thus said story regarding homestead land - 17 mi. S.W. of Girvin. He bought one section of land one mile N. of Girvin and it is still in the family.

We had read about Saskatchewan in the newspapers and wanted to see for ourselves.
MRS. LENA KERNEN BACON

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you were under 18 years of age at that time)
9. How did you learn about the weather? (through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

My father divided Western Canada, fell in love with the province of wheat farms. He bought a section of land one mile north of Girvin, Sask., and came home with an intention of homesteading. Shortly after, he bought one section of land - 17 miles southwest of Girvin. We took up the family one mile north of Girvin and it was still in the family.

We had read about Saskatchewan in newspapers and went to see for ourselves in 1921.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They considered it a pipe-dream even my father didn't want me to go later or if my heart was fixed nothing could stop me.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other people)?

I traveled alone with my five year old daughter.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

This is also recorded in my manuscript in the hands of Mrs. E. Kerner.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

With my two brothers Fred and Chas. Kernern at Girvin.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? 17 mi. S.W. of Girvin, Sask.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

REGINA.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Mining - This is also recorded in my manuscript.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy? In this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

In 1915 I went to Canada for wallpaper and bought carpet to cover a homemade lounge, and lace to make collars for Christmas gifts.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

I was forced to change my decision because of the severe winters and my daughter was already to enter school. During the summer taught all the children in the area at a tent. There were seven in all. One year later, with thirty-two, we had a schoolhouse.

In 1915 I went to Eaton's for wallpaper and Imperial Carpets to cover homemade drapes, and lace to make collars for Christmas gifts.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? X

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea or staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Yes, intended to make it my home.

I was forced to change my daughter's school during the summer because of the winter school. During the summer we taught all the children in the area and a total of nine were sworn in all. One year later, with thirteen, we had a schoolhouse.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1920? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, our family moved to Virginia in 1919.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Most all the farmers are still on their farms fifteen years and my home still stands.

During the Great Depression, many families moved into the city.

36. If so, some members of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

School and Rockefellor. The first public community school was built by Rockefeller.

The School (Ellen) taught in that area but now resides living in Rockford and resides in the Chicago City in North America.

37. If so, any of your family or friends were forced to have something in the district mission, or have given dates wherever possible, such as emigration, the first automobiles, or those originating to the first stage, etc.

I was the first professional nurse in all three parts. In 1918 and cared for all the obstetrical cases without a doctor.

One case of pneumonia, brought Typhoid. The nearest man with a hospital over shoulder for a man with a disability over.

- Bacon who was in Canada with me, she married, lives on a farm near Woodward, Okla.

They have 3 sons, 2 are in the service of their country. The youngest at 14 years old on the farm.

The eldest Mr. Bill Tom Elizabeth Bull and Grand Michael Bull.

Churches and schools, higher education, factories, combines, high dollar farming implements, autos, and a known how to take care of the chin when the severe cold and drought leaves you with arthritis.
